awd_titl_txt: Photoswitchable Polymers for 2-Step Dry Transfer of 2D Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Graphene and other atomically thin materials have very attractive mechanical, electrical and thermal properties and their mass production via chemical vapor deposition has greatly improved the opportunities to scale up the production of devices that employ them. However, before these materials can be used, they need to be transferred from their growth substrate to a target substrate for microelectronics devices. This award addresses the transfer step, which is a roadblock to manufacturing scalability. Historically, transfer has been accomplished by so-called wet methods, where the growth substrate is dissolved away. These are slow, wasteful, and often lead to relatively high levels of contamination. Dry transfer methods developed here provide an attractive rapid and “cleaner” alternative. Because these materials are so thin, they need to be supported at all times and polymers are an attractive medium for removing the materials from their growth substrate and depositing them on the target substrate. High and low adhesion is required for the first and second steps, respectively. The challenge being addressed in this award is the development of novel polymers, whose adhesion can be switched on or off by shining light on them. It is expected that successful development of such polymers will place the US in a leadership role in manufacturing these atomically thin materials and promote the fabrication of next generation electronics to be found in phones, computers, cars and televisions. There is extensive educational outreach to K-12 and STEM audiences that highlights switchable adhesion and the polymers developed in the course of the research.

The goals of the research are to (i) develop a new class of photoswitchable adhesives that is tailored specifically to the 2-step, dry transfer of graphene via (ii) a thorough and deep characterization of the interactions of all the interfaces that play a role in the transfer process and (iii) the design and fabrication of a separation tool that is common to both transfer steps based on the understanding obtained in the first two steps. This multidisciplinary effort is highly coupled in that the development of this class of polymers will be guided by both the characterization and tool development efforts, which will both feedback into the fine tuning of composition, architecture and associated adhesion characteristics of the polymers. From a fundamental materials perspective, the impact of polymer composition and architecture (e.g., networks vs surface-bound brushes) on the photoresponsive change in order and topology will be unveiled and inform the design of next generation “smart” adhesives. These light-responsive adhesive characteristics will be judiciously characterized and applied to the efficient, large area 2-step dry (patterned) transfer of graphene using an innovative and efficient advanced manufacturing process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Graphene and other 2D materials have very attractive mechanical, electrical and thermal properties and their mass production via chemical vapor deposition has greatly improved the opportunities to scale up the production of devices that employ them. This proposal addresses the remaining roadblock to scalability: transferring large area 2D materials from their growth substrates to target substrates useful in electronics. Historically, transfer has been accomplished by so-called wet methods, which are slow, wasteful, and often leads to relatively high levels of contamination. Dry transfer provides an attractive rapid and “clean” alternative. To-date, dry transfer of 2D materials has leveraged fracture mechanics to achieve adhesion differentials with the use of polymer supporting layers. The majority of efforts have been directed at one-step transfer processes where polymers are suitable target substrates. However most polymers are not compatible with subsequent processing steps in electronic and related applications where 2D materials need to be deposited on silicon wafers. Consequently two-step processes must be considered where the 2D material is first transferred to a polymer-coated substrate and then to the target substrate. This requires the use of a “smart” polymer with selective or switchable adhesion being high with the 2D material in the first step and low adhesion for the second step. A systematic design, preparation, and characterization of azobenzene-containing liquid crystal elastomers (LCEs) has enabled room temperature photoswitchable adhesion. Simply toggling between UV light (365 nm) and blue light (470 nm) exposure in a tack test gave a Δσad of 2×, despite the slow pull-off rate (0.6 mm/min), while also showing no significant loss in adhesion over the course of a few cycles. The viscoelastic behavior of the LCE has been characterized along with a fracture mechanics analysis of the adhesive interactions between the polymer and glass. A parallel effort aimed at transferring graphene from sapphire to silicon via an in-depth characterization of the interactions under a range of combinations of tension and shear has pointed to the possibility of effecting one-step transfer under shear loading based on opposing trends of the interactions between the two interfaces.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of the proposal is attributed to (i) the extensive development of a new class of photoswitchable adhesives that is tailored specifically to the 2-step, dry transfer of graphene via (ii) a thorough and deep characterization of the interactions of all the interfaces that play a role in the transfer process in conjunction with (iii) the development of a separation tool that is common to both transfer steps. This multidisciplinary effort is highly coupled in that the development of this class of polymers has been guided by both the characterization and tool development efforts, which both fedback into the fine tuning of composition, architecture and associated adhesion characteristics of the polymers. As a result, both fundamental and applied discoveries have result from the proposed research efforts. From a fundamental materials perspective, the impact of polymer composition and architecture (e.g., networks vs. surface-bound brushes) on the photoresponsive change in order and topology, along with fatigue resistance (cycling stability) were unveiled and informed the design of next generation “smart” adhesives. Through the proposed interdisciplinary collaboration the light responsive adhesive characteristics have been characterized and applied to the efficient, large area 2-step dry transfer of graphene using an innovative advanced manufacturing process.

Broader Impacts

The successful outcome of this proposal has had a far-reaching impact in the nanomanufacturing arena for the fabrication of next generation electronics found in everyday appliances from phones to computers and televisions. Adhesion is a fundamental and ubiquitous technology, but the design of adhesive materials is largely empirical. Thus, the deep characterization and modeling efforts conducted here have served as a template for other areas of manufacturing that rely on switchable adhesives. In the course of this research, three graduate students and one undergraduate student (including two women) have learned about polymer synthesis, adhesion characterization as well as modeling and simulation in a unique, multidisciplinary and diverse environment. One female PhD has joined the microelectronics workforce. The PI’s recognize that the research efforts in materials and mechanics innovation will be greatly accelerated by having a diverse scientific workforce. As such, the PI’s and their groups participated in early career engagement, fostering diversity in STEM, education, and outreach. To this end, the PI’s followed three routes to integrate the proposed materials and methods into education and outreach: 1) a hands-on teaching module surrounding next generation adhesive materials and protocols to measuring adhesion as part of the recently re-established polymer science and engineering lab course (CHE 395E), 2) a video has been generated that demonstrates switchable adhesion and 3) materials developed here have been used for photothermal testing as part of a new Freshman Research Initiative (FRI).

 


Last Modified: 12/24/2024
Modified by: Kenneth M Liechti

    Two step dry transfer of graphene

This proposal addresses the remaining roadblock to scalability: transferring large area 2D materials from their growth substrates to target substrates useful in electronics.
